body: @DanielNoord Would you like to take a look at this? I'm unable to reproduce it with `main`.

I'm able to reproduce this.

Adding `pylint.extensions.docparams` to `load-plugins` and `no-docstring-rgx=__.*__` makes this warning emit for me.

I have a feeling it might be because of the `*` because the message reports it is missing for `args` instead of `*args`. I will take a look!

issue.title: Fix asterisks parsing of ``mising-param-doc``

labels.name: False Positive ðŸ¦Ÿ
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
- [x] Add yourself to CONTRIBUTORS if you are a new contributor.
- [x] Add a ChangeLog entry describing what your PR does.
- [x] If it's a new feature, or an important bug fix, add a What's New entry in
      `doc/whatsnew/<current release.rst>`.
- [x] Write a good description on what the PR does.

## Type of Changes

|     | Type                   |
| --- | ---------------------- |
| âœ“   | :bug: Bug fix          |

## Description

Based on https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/1.5.2/ext/example_numpy.html#example-numpy and https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/1.5.2/ext/example_google.html#example-google I think we should include the asterisk in the docstring. 

For the `Sphinx` style I'm still not 100% sure but a bit of googling seems to show that most users also use asterisks in that style. Their own documentation does not include an example:
https://pythonhosted.org/an_example_pypi_project/sphinx.html#full-code-exampl

Closes #3733

issue.title: [v2.12 Regression] Asterisk argument `mising-param-doc` vs `anomalous-backslash-in-string`

labels.name: False Positive ðŸ¦Ÿ
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
### Bug description

Take the following function:

```py
def echo(*args):
    """
    Print the given arguments.
    """
    print(*args)
```

The `args` parameter can be added to the docstring (in Sphinx style) in 3 ways:

1. `:param args: Arguments to print.`
    This works with sphinx and pylint 2.11.1 and earlier (before #5175).  With pylint 2.12.0 and later it causes the following errors
   > echo.py:4:0: W9015: "*args" missing in parameter documentation (missing-param-doc)
   > echo.py:4:0: W9017: "args" differing in parameter documentation (differing-param-doc)
2. `:param *args: Arguments to print.`
    This works with pylint, but causes the following error with sphinx:
    > echo.py:docstring of echo.echo:3:Inline emphasis start-string without end-string.
3. `:param \*args: Arguments to print.`
    This works with sphinx, but causes the following error with pylint:
   > W1401: Anomalous backslash in string: '\*'. String constant might be missing an r prefix. (anomalous-backslash-in-string)

### Configuration

```ini
[MASTER]
load-plugins=pylint.extensions.docparams
```


### Command used

```shell
pylint echo.py
```


### Pylint output

For method 1 (with pylint 2.12.1):

    echo.py:4:0: W9015: "*args" missing in parameter documentation (missing-param-doc)
    echo.py:4:0: W9017: "args" differing in parameter documentation (differing-param-doc)

For method 2:

No errors.

For method 3:

    echo.py:8:11: W1401: Anomalous backslash in string: '\*'. String constant might be missing an r prefix. (anomalous-backslash-in-string)


### Expected behavior

I would expect pylint to accept the syntaxes that Sphinx does (1 and 3 from above).

I'd prefer if pylint rejected syntaxes which Sphinx rejects (2 from above).  However, since Sphinx accepts asterisk-without-backslash for Google- and NumPy-style docstrings (as requested in #3733) if these can't be easily distinguished by pylint, it'd probably be preferable to accept them all.

Note:  This issue has affected other linters and it was noted that sphinx.ext.napoleon (which adds support for NumPy and Google style docstrings) auto-escapes \* at the beginning of arguments:  https://github.com/peterjc/flake8-rst-docstrings/issues/18#issuecomment-661040265  This is likely why those styles differ from Sphinx style in what is accepted.

### Pylint version

```shell
pylint 2.12.1
Sphinx 4.3.0
```


### OS / Environment

Debian GNU/Linux bookworm/sid

### Additional dependencies

_No response_

issue.title: Improve documentation for star parameters

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: enhance or introduce a new feature

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

It is not clear to me how to document a star parameter of a variadic function and whether the parameter name should be prefixed with \*, \\\*, or nothing.  This is particularly true in Sphinx style, but also applies to Google and NumPy styles to some extent (\*args and \*\*kwargs appear in [an example](https://sphinxcontrib-napoleon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/example_google.html), but it's not clear if that's the preferred or only syntax).  This has caused confusion for linters, such as:

* peterjc/flake8-rst-docstrings#18
* PyCQA/pylint#3733
* PyCQA/pylint#5406

It appears that both no-prefix and backslash-star are accepted for Sphinx style, and that all three are accepted for Google and NumPy style (due to auto-escaping in sphinx.ext.napoleon as noted in https://github.com/peterjc/flake8-rst-docstrings/issues/18#issuecomment-661040265 ).  Is this correct?  Are any styles preferred?

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I had checked for examples in both [Describing code in Sphinx](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/tutorial/describing-code.html#documenting-python-objects) or [The Python Domain](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/domains.html#info-field-lists).  I'd recommend adding an example to both with the preferred style, and discussing other supported styles in The Python Domain.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Keeping the status quo is always an option.  We can weigh the current ambiguity and confusion against the effort to write and maintain the docs.

Thanks for considering,
Kevin
